{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3023284,"name":"Travis Hoffman","username":"Travis_Hoffman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/travis_hoffman/{size}/161072_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-15T02:24:30.851Z","cooked":"

We here on Team 48 decided to design and build a turret for a ball-shooting mechanism for our 25th anniversary robot, xtremachen25. This was the first time we ever put such a thing our our bot. Better late than never, right? We also did not like the right-angle COTS packaging options for climber gearboxes to pair with our dual AndyMark Climbers In a Box (which both worked just fine #ad). Add to this our obsession, for once in our existence, to have a robot weigh significantly south of the weight limit and our possession of 2 Markforged printers, and we said ‚ÄúWhy not? Let‚Äôs have some fun!‚Äù

So we went a bit Onyx crazy. Here is what resulted. The herringbone gear pattern you see in the turret and climber gearbox were employed with reliable success at Finger Lakes. Additionally, the robot weighs around 118 pounds, which it turns out is plenty enough to add our 2nd set of hooks for higher rung climbs, along with a few other mods.

Team 48 2022 Herringbone Turret Drive1800√ó4000 1.37 MB
Team 48 2022 Climber Gearbox2160√ó3840 393 KB

Here‚Äôs a Behind the Glass video of one of our qualifying matches where you can see the turret and climber in operation: https://youtu.be/Wh8XLmzMAYA?t=74

We had a lot of new things and new people to get up to speed at our first event, and competition results didn‚Äôt end up the way we would have liked, but we are excited for the potential of this robot and drive team. We‚Äôre back in the shop tomorrow to begin upgrades and further practice. I am very much Looking Forward to competing at the Buckeye and Midwest Regionals to see what we can achieve following some iteration time.

I will be posting the complete CAD to GrabCAD sometime in the coming weeks, once we are done making changes throughout the competition season. If anyone has questions I‚Äôd be glad to answer them here or on the aforementioned post containing links to our pack-n-go‚Äôd ‚Äúfinal‚Äù product.

Very surprised those plastic gears are holding up in the final stage of a climbing gearbox. But risks sometimes pay rewards! Can you estimate the tooth bending load?

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-18T14:55:57.951Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":563,"readers_count":562,"score":132.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":405743,"topic_slug":"frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox/405743/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3025297,"name":"Adam Reed","username":"A_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/a_reed/{size}/122284_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-18T16:10:03.688Z","cooked":"

TBH, I didn‚Äôt bother to run the math in the process of the build as this is more or less an experiment* with direct replacement WCP/VP gears waiting to be swapped in. So far with one competition (with limited climbing) and further practice at home we‚Äôve had no issues. We likely will be inspecting them again tonight as we have been attempting to implement our traverse hooks.

I‚Äôll have to blow the dust off my college machine design text book or look through my old revision AGMA standards and work out the approximate numbers.

*I had already made the turret gears parametric so it took all of an hour to make up 4 gears for this application and get them printing. We don‚Äôt keep much stock of WCP/VP‚Äôs gearing and were concerned with the lead time to acquire the direct swaps.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-18T16:16:03.142Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":534,"readers_count":533,"score":116.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":405743,"topic_slug":"frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox","display_username":"Adam Reed","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":22221,"username":"nuclearnerd","name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":5373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Mechanical Engineer/CAD Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox/405743/4","custom_user_title":"Lead Mechanical Engineer/CAD Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3025358,"name":"Brendan Simons, 5406","username":"nuclearnerd","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-18T17:15:44.450Z","cooked":"
A_Reed:

n‚Äôt bother to run the math in the process of the build as this is more or less an experiment* with direct replacement WCP/VP gears waiting to be swapped in. So far with one competition (with limited climbing) and further practice at home we‚Äôve had no issues. We likely will be inspecting them again ton

No need for the Agma standards yet. I just need:

  • the force on the winch rope (~75 lb ?, plus some extra for acceleration, double for single-hook climbs)
  • multiplied by the winch radius (0.75 in?) to get winch torque
  • divided by the final gear radius (1.5 in?) to get force on the gear‚Äôs teeth

My guesses come out to about 38 lb per tooth (the herringbone helps share that over multiple teeth), which actually isn‚Äôt as much as I thought.

Do you do have an insert in that hex bore? I‚Äôve heard that 1/2" hex strips easily inside 3DP parts without one.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2022-03-18T17:15:44.450Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":464,"readers_count":463,"score":132.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":405743,"topic_slug":"frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox","display_username":"Brendan Simons, 5406","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/bearings/QTY-5-Aluminum-Insert-for-3D-Printed-Parts-p300867737","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":9}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22221,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox/405743/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3025367,"name":"Adam Reed","username":"A_Reed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/a_reed/{size}/122284_2.png","created_at":"2022-03-18T17:24:28.191Z","cooked":"

All of those numbers are about right. I‚Äôm trying to remember the PD I used for the final stage off the top of my head. It is either 8, 10, or 12 for a 32T output gear. So, 4", 3.2" or 2.66" diameter respectively.

No insert, we have two shells of continuous CF in the walls (4-6 walls of Onyx) of the hex bore and it extends into a hub for a total hex face width/bearing area width of about 1.125" to prevent blowout.

Screenshot 2022-03-18 133221739√ó501 39.4 KB
Screenshot 2022-03-18 133108775√ó532 42.1 KB

Simons, 5406","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuclearnerd/{size}/7324_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":5373,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Lead Mechanical Engineer/CAD Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/frc-team-48-onyx-herringbone-turret-and-climber-gearbox/405743/6","custom_user_title":"Lead Mechanical Engineer/CAD Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3037321,"name":"Travis Hoffman","username":"Travis_Hoffman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/travis_hoffman/{size}/161072_2.png","created_at":"2022-04-05T02:37:37.825Z","cooked":"

We won‚Äôt speak of the evils of Buckeye, but we believe the full traversal climb is finally ready for primetime at Midwest.

The herringbone printed reinforced Onyx gears continue to perform well. Our only major maintenance requirement so far was to swap out the locking gear our metal climb lock dowels press into. We observed some wear there. We could probably just clock the gear 180 degrees and use it again, but why risk it?

The carbon fiber rod secondary climb hooks can be added to the ‚Äúthings with lots of 3D printed parts that scare me‚Äù category. The upper hook clamp and the lower clamping pivot bracket are reinforced Onyx. I believe at FLR, I weighed both hook assemblies (at the time without actuation cylinders) at 1.7 lbs. total.

All hook pivots have been coupled to the main frame via beefy reinforced Onyx brackets this entire season - the OG brackets are still on there and rock solid. That continues to boggle my mind, especially after some of our more ‚Äúinteresting‚Äù prior climbs. But these light 3D printed systems are slowly convincing me to trust their use in higher-load applications.

In other news, we also added something to our shooter (visible in the video) that makes it behave much better (famous last words).

Linking the threads‚Ä¶

FRC 48 Team E.L.I.T.E. - Xtrƒìmachƒìn 25 CAD Release CAD
Hello, [Full Robot] Team E.L.I.T.E.'s resident CAD guy here to drop a link to our 2022 FIRST Rapid React robot Xtrƒìmachƒìn 25 . This is our 25th season of Encouraging Learning In Technology and Engineering and while we came up short in some aspects of the competition I and all of my fellow mentors are proud of the efforts our students put forth this season. We got XM25 off to a sluggish start in Rochester and without the ability to traverse were easily taken out in the quarterfinals. We don‚Äôt‚Ä¶

It‚Äôs been great fun on our team this season seeing how many New England and other teams have ended up with some form of herringbone gear application on their robots. At least a few of us have postulated that our visit from Ohio to Battlecry last summer may have contributed to this proliferation in at least some small fashion, for at least a few teams.

I‚Äôm not looking to ‚Äúquantify inspiration‚Äù; I‚Äôm just genuinely curious if anyone who was at Battlecry (or elsewhere who read this thread in 2022) decided to add 3D-printed herringbone as a result of their interaction with our team, either directly at Battlecry or via this thread.

Herringbone wrist joints, in particular, seem to be very popular this year #sidewaysturret

Good luck in 2023, #teamherringbone!
